screens.headline: Want to collect $350 every month from stocks you already own?
screens.text: Covered calls let you become a 'landlord' of your stocks - collecting rent while keeping your property. In 8 minutes, you'll learn the strategy that generates 70% of options income.

screens.headline: Covered Call = Selling the Upside
screens.text: A covered call means you OWN 100 shares of a stock, and SELL someone the right to buy it from you at a higher price. They pay you a premium for this right. You keep the premium no matter what happens.

screens.headline: Think of it like being a landlord
screens.text: You own a house worth $200,000 (your stock). A tenant says 'I'll pay you $1,000/month rent, and I have the option to buy your house for $220,000 anytime this year.' You agree. Every month you collect $1,000. If they buy it, great - you profit $20,000 plus all the rent you collected. If they don't buy it, you keep your house AND all the rent money.

reveal_sections.label: Your house = Stock you own (100 shares)
Option to buy = Call option you sold

cards.definition: You OWN the 100 shares already (not naked/risky)
The price someone can buy your stock at
cards.example: Own stock at $180, sell $190 call = $190 strike

cards.definition: The income you receive upfront (yours to keep)
When your stock gets 'called away' (sold at strike)
cards.example: Stock hits $195, you sell at $190 (still profit!)

screens.question: You own 100 shares of MSFT at $300. You sell a $320 call for $5/share. What's the MOST income you can make on this trade?
options: $500 (just the premium)
$2,000 (the stock gain)
$2,500 (premium + stock gain)
Unlimited (if stock goes to $400)
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! You get $500 premium + $2,000 stock gain ($320 strike - $300 cost) = $2,500 max profit. Your upside is CAPPED at the strike price - that's the trade-off for collecting premium.
screens.explanation_wrong: Remember: You collect the premium ($500) AND can profit up to the strike price ($320). But you cap your gains there - even if stock hits $400, you sell at $320.

screens.question: What's the biggest RISK of selling covered calls?
options: You lose your premium
The stock crashes (you lose on the stock value)
You have to buy 100 shares
You owe unlimited money
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! The premium gives you a small cushion, but if the stock crashes from $180 to $120, you lose $6,000 on the stock (minus the $350 premium = $5,650 net loss). You own the stock risk!
screens.explanation_wrong: Think about it: You ALREADY own the stock. If it crashes, you lose money on those shares. The premium you collected just reduces the loss slightly.

screens.question: You own 100 AAPL at $180. You sell a $190 call for $3.50 premium. A month later, AAPL is at $185. What happens?
options: You lose money because AAPL didn't hit $190
Option expires worthless - you keep stock + $350 premium
You have to sell your stock at $185
You owe the buyer money
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! Stock stayed below $190 strike, so the option expires worthless. You keep your 100 shares (now worth $185) AND keep the $350 premium. You can sell another covered call next month and do it again!
screens.explanation_wrong: The buyer only exercises if the stock is ABOVE the strike ($190). Since AAPL is at $185, they let it expire. You keep everything - stock + premium.

screens.headline: Dividends & Early Assignment - CRITICAL Risk
screens.text: If your stock pays dividends and your sold call is ITM near ex-dividend date, you face HIGH early assignment risk. Call buyers exercise the night BEFORE ex-div to capture the dividend. You lose: 1) Your shares (assigned), 2) The dividend (buyer gets it). This is the #1 covered call mistake. Always close ITM calls before ex-div dates!

cards.definition: The cutoff date to receive the dividend. Own stock BEFORE this date = get dividend
cards.example: Ex-div Friday. Own stock Thursday night = get dividend. Buy Friday = no dividend. Options buyers know this!

cards.definition: ITM call buyers exercise night before ex-div to capture dividend
cards.example: Stock pays $0.50 dividend tomorrow. Your $180 call ITM at $182. Buyer exercises tonight, captures $50 dividend, you lose stock + dividend.

cards.definition: Hold stock for dividend, THEN sell covered call after ex-div date
cards.example: Own JEPI (pays $0.50 monthly). Wait for ex-div date, collect dividend, THEN sell calls. You keep dividend + premium!

cards.definition: Option prices drop by ~dividend amount on ex-div date
cards.example: Stock $100, pays $1 dividend. After ex-div, stock opens $99, calls drop ~$1. This is normal, expected.

screens.question: You sold $180 covered calls on AAPL. Stock is $183 (ITM). Ex-dividend date is tomorrow ($0.25 dividend). What's your risk?
options: No risk - expiration is 2 weeks away
HIGH RISK - likely assigned tonight, lose stock + dividend
Low risk - $0.25 dividend is too small to matter
Medium risk - 50/50 chance
screens.explanation_correct: CRITICAL awareness! Call buyer thinks: 'Exercise tonight, capture $25 dividend tomorrow, vs wait 2 weeks.' They exercise. You wake up: shares gone, no dividend. ALWAYS close ITM calls 1-2 days before ex-div date. $25 dividend may seem small, but losing it + shares = bad outcome!
screens.explanation_wrong: This is THE most common early assignment trigger! Even small dividends ($0.25) incentivize early exercise. Buyer captures $25 dividend by exercising. You lose shares + dividend. Rule: Close ITM covered calls 1-2 days before ex-dividend date. Non-negotiable!

screens.question: Best covered call strategy for dividend stocks (like JEPI, SCHD)?
options: Sell calls anytime - dividends don't matter
Never sell calls on dividend stocks
Wait until AFTER ex-div date, collect dividend, THEN sell calls
Sell calls only far OTM (>10%)
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect strategy! Timeline: 1) Hold stock through ex-div date ‚Üí collect dividend, 2) Next day, sell covered calls ‚Üí collect premium, 3) Both dividends + premiums = double income! Never sell ITM calls before ex-div on dividend stocks - you'll lose both income streams!
screens.explanation_wrong: Smart dividend strategy: Own stock ‚Üí Collect dividend (ex-div date) ‚Üí THEN sell calls. This way you get BOTH dividend income AND premium income. Selling calls BEFORE ex-div = risk early assignment = you lose dividend. Timing matters!
